text: SCENE I. Before an alehouse on a heath.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Enter Hostess and Sly

author: William Shakespeare
text: SLY.

author: William Shakespeare
text: I’ll pheeze you, in faith.

author: William Shakespeare
text: HOSTESS.

author: William Shakespeare
text: A pair of stocks, you rogue!

author: William Shakespeare
text: SLY.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Y’are a baggage; the Slys are no rogues; look in the chronicles: we

author: William Shakespeare
text: came in with Richard Conqueror. Therefore, paucas pallabris; let the

author: William Shakespeare
text: world slide. Sessa!

author: William Shakespeare
text: HOSTESS.

author: William Shakespeare
text: You will not pay for the glasses you have burst?

author: William Shakespeare
text: SLY.

author: William Shakespeare
text: No, not a denier. Go by, Saint Jeronimy, go to thy cold bed and warm

author: William Shakespeare
text: thee.

author: William Shakespeare
text: HOSTESS.

author: William Shakespeare
text: I know my remedy; I must go fetch the third-borough.

author: William Shakespeare
text: [Exit]

author: William Shakespeare
text: SLY.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Third, or fourth, or fifth borough, I’ll answer him by law. I’ll not

author: William Shakespeare
text: budge an inch, boy: let him come, and kindly.

author: William Shakespeare
text: [Lies down on the ground, and falls asleep.]

author: William Shakespeare
text: Horns winded. Enter a Lord from hunting, with Huntsmen and Servants.

author: William Shakespeare
text: LORD.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Huntsman, I charge thee, tender well my hounds;

author: William Shakespeare
text: Brach Merriman, the poor cur is emboss’d,

author: William Shakespeare
text: And couple Clowder with the deep-mouth’d brach.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Saw’st thou not, boy, how Silver made it good

author: William Shakespeare
text: At the hedge-corner, in the coldest fault?

author: William Shakespeare
text: I would not lose the dog for twenty pound.

author: William Shakespeare
text: FIRST HUNTSMAN.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Why, Bellman is as good as he, my lord;

author: William Shakespeare
text: He cried upon it at the merest loss,

author: William Shakespeare
text: And twice today pick’d out the dullest scent;

author: William Shakespeare
text: Trust me, I take him for the better dog.

author: William Shakespeare
text: LORD.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Thou art a fool: if Echo were as fleet,

author: William Shakespeare
text: I would esteem him worth a dozen such.

author: William Shakespeare
text: But sup them well, and look unto them all;

author: William Shakespeare
text: Tomorrow I intend to hunt again.

author: William Shakespeare
text: FIRST HUNTSMAN.

author: William Shakespeare
text: I will, my lord.

author: William Shakespeare
text: LORD.

author: William Shakespeare
text: [Sees Sly.] What’s here? One dead, or drunk?

author: William Shakespeare
text: See, doth he breathe?

author: William Shakespeare
text: SECOND HUNTSMAN.

author: William Shakespeare
text: He breathes, my lord. Were he not warm’d with ale,

author: William Shakespeare
text: This were a bed but cold to sleep so soundly.

author: William Shakespeare
text: LORD.

author: William Shakespeare
text: O monstrous beast! how like a swine he lies!

author: William Shakespeare
text: Grim death, how foul and loathsome is thine image!

author: William Shakespeare
text: Sirs, I will practise on this drunken man.

author: William Shakespeare
text: What think you, if he were convey’d to bed,

author: William Shakespeare
text: Wrapp’d in sweet clothes, rings put upon his fingers,

author: William Shakespeare
text: A most delicious banquet by his bed,

author: William Shakespeare
text: And brave attendants near him when he wakes,

author: William Shakespeare
text: Would not the beggar then forget himself?

author: William Shakespeare
text: FIRST HUNTSMAN.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Believe me, lord, I think he cannot choose.

author: William Shakespeare
text: SECOND HUNTSMAN.

author: William Shakespeare
text: It would seem strange unto him when he wak’d.

author: William Shakespeare
text: LORD.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Even as a flattering dream or worthless fancy.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Then take him up, and manage well the jest.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Carry him gently to my fairest chamber,

author: William Shakespeare
text: And hang it round with all my wanton pictures;

author: William Shakespeare
text: Balm his foul head in warm distilled waters,

author: William Shakespeare
text: And burn sweet wood to make the lodging sweet.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Procure me music ready when he wakes,

author: William Shakespeare
text: To make a dulcet and a heavenly sound;

author: William Shakespeare
text: And if he chance to speak, be ready straight,

author: William Shakespeare
text: And with a low submissive reverence

author: William Shakespeare
text: Say ‘What is it your honour will command?’

author: William Shakespeare
text: Let one attend him with a silver basin

author: William Shakespeare
text: Full of rose-water and bestrew’d with flowers;

author: William Shakespeare
text: Another bear the ewer, the third a diaper,

author: William Shakespeare
text: And say ‘Will’t please your lordship cool your hands?’

author: William Shakespeare
text: Someone be ready with a costly suit,

author: William Shakespeare
text: And ask him what apparel he will wear;

author: William Shakespeare
text: Another tell him of his hounds and horse,

author: William Shakespeare
text: And that his lady mourns at his disease.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Persuade him that he hath been lunatic;

author: William Shakespeare
text: And, when he says he is—say that he dreams,

author: William Shakespeare
text: For he is nothing but a mighty lord.

author: William Shakespeare
text: This do, and do it kindly, gentle sirs;

author: William Shakespeare
text: It will be pastime passing excellent,

author: William Shakespeare
text: If it be husbanded with modesty.

author: William Shakespeare
text: FIRST HUNTSMAN.

author: William Shakespeare
text: My lord, I warrant you we will play our part,

author: William Shakespeare
text: As he shall think by our true diligence,

author: William Shakespeare
text: He is no less than what we say he is.

author: William Shakespeare
text: LORD.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Take him up gently, and to bed with him,

author: William Shakespeare
text: And each one to his office when he wakes.

author: William Shakespeare
text: [Sly is borne out. A trumpet sounds.]

author: William Shakespeare
text: Sirrah, go see what trumpet ’tis that sounds.

author: William Shakespeare
text: [Exit Servant.]

author: William Shakespeare
text: Belike some noble gentleman that means,

author: William Shakespeare
text: Travelling some journey, to repose him here.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Re-enter Servant.

author: William Shakespeare
text: How now! who is it?

author: William Shakespeare
text: SERVANT.

author: William Shakespeare
text: An it please your honour, players

author: William Shakespeare
text: That offer service to your lordship.

author: William Shakespeare
text: LORD.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Bid them come near.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Enter Players.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Now, fellows, you are welcome.

author: William Shakespeare
text: PLAYERS.

author: William Shakespeare
text: We thank your honour.

author: William Shakespeare
text: LORD.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Do you intend to stay with me tonight?

author: William Shakespeare
text: PLAYER.

author: William Shakespeare
text: So please your lordship to accept our duty.

author: William Shakespeare
text: LORD.

author: William Shakespeare
text: With all my heart. This fellow I remember

author: William Shakespeare
text: Since once he play’d a farmer’s eldest son;

author: William Shakespeare
text: ’Twas where you woo’d the gentlewoman so well.

author: William Shakespeare
text: I have forgot your name; but, sure, that part

author: William Shakespeare
text: Was aptly fitted and naturally perform’d.

author: William Shakespeare
text: PLAYER.

author: William Shakespeare
text: I think ’twas Soto that your honour means.

author: William Shakespeare
text: LORD.

author: William Shakespeare
text: ’Tis very true; thou didst it excellent.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Well, you are come to me in happy time,

author: William Shakespeare
text: The rather for I have some sport in hand

author: William Shakespeare
text: Wherein your cunning can assist me much.

author: William Shakespeare
text: There is a lord will hear you play tonight;

author: William Shakespeare
text: But I am doubtful of your modesties,

author: William Shakespeare
text: Lest, over-eying of his odd behaviour,—

author: William Shakespeare
text: For yet his honour never heard a play,—

author: William Shakespeare
text: You break into some merry passion

author: William Shakespeare
text: And so offend him; for I tell you, sirs,

author: William Shakespeare
text: If you should smile, he grows impatient.

author: William Shakespeare
text: PLAYER.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Fear not, my lord; we can contain ourselves,

author: William Shakespeare
text: Were he the veriest antick in the world.

author: William Shakespeare
text: LORD.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Go, sirrah, take them to the buttery,

author: William Shakespeare
text: And give them friendly welcome everyone:

author: William Shakespeare
text: Let them want nothing that my house affords.

author: William Shakespeare
text: [Exit one with the Players.]

author: William Shakespeare
text: Sirrah, go you to Barthol’mew my page,

author: William Shakespeare
text: And see him dress’d in all suits like a lady;

author: William Shakespeare
text: That done, conduct him to the drunkard’s chamber,

author: William Shakespeare
text: And call him ‘madam,’ do him obeisance.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Tell him from me—as he will win my love,—

author: William Shakespeare
text: He bear himself with honourable action,

author: William Shakespeare
text: Such as he hath observ’d in noble ladies

author: William Shakespeare
text: Unto their lords, by them accomplished;

author: William Shakespeare
text: Such duty to the drunkard let him do,

author: William Shakespeare
text: With soft low tongue and lowly courtesy,

author: William Shakespeare
text: And say ‘What is’t your honour will command,

author: William Shakespeare
text: Wherein your lady and your humble wife

author: William Shakespeare
text: May show her duty and make known her love?’

author: William Shakespeare
text: And then with kind embracements, tempting kisses,

author: William Shakespeare
text: And with declining head into his bosom,

author: William Shakespeare
text: Bid him shed tears, as being overjoy’d

author: William Shakespeare
text: To see her noble lord restor’d to health,

author: William Shakespeare
text: Who for this seven years hath esteemed him

author: William Shakespeare
text: No better than a poor and loathsome beggar.

author: William Shakespeare
text: And if the boy have not a woman’s gift

author: William Shakespeare
text: To rain a shower of commanded tears,

author: William Shakespeare
text: An onion will do well for such a shift,

author: William Shakespeare
text: Which, in a napkin being close convey’d,

author: William Shakespeare
text: Shall in despite enforce a watery eye.

author: William Shakespeare
text: See this dispatch’d with all the haste thou canst;

author: William Shakespeare
text: Anon I’ll give thee more instructions.

author: William Shakespeare
text: [Exit Servant.]

author: William Shakespeare
text: I know the boy will well usurp the grace,

author: William Shakespeare
text: Voice, gait, and action of a gentlewoman;

author: William Shakespeare
text: I long to hear him call the drunkard husband;

author: William Shakespeare
text: And how my men will stay themselves from laughter

author: William Shakespeare
text: When they do homage to this simple peasant.

author: William Shakespeare
text: I’ll in to counsel them; haply my presence

author: William Shakespeare
text: May well abate the over-merry spleen,

author: William Shakespeare
text: Which otherwise would grow into extremes.

author: William Shakespeare
text: [Exeunt.]

author: William Shakespeare
text: SCENE II. A bedchamber in the Lord’s house.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Sly is discovered in a rich nightgown, with Attendants: some with

author: William Shakespeare
text: apparel, basin, ewer, and other appurtenances; and Lord, dressed like a

author: William Shakespeare
text: servant.

author: William Shakespeare
text: SLY.

author: William Shakespeare
text: For God’s sake! a pot of small ale.

author: William Shakespeare
text: FIRST SERVANT.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Will’t please your lordship drink a cup of sack?

author: William Shakespeare
text: SECOND SERVANT.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Will’t please your honour taste of these conserves?

author: William Shakespeare
text: THIRD SERVANT.

author: William Shakespeare
text: What raiment will your honour wear today?

author: William Shakespeare
text: SLY.

author: William Shakespeare
text: I am Christophero Sly; call not me honour nor lordship. I ne’er drank

author: William Shakespeare
text: sack in my life; and if you give me any conserves, give me conserves of

author: William Shakespeare
text: beef. Ne’er ask me what raiment I’ll wear, for I have no more doublets

author: William Shakespeare
text: than backs, no more stockings than legs, nor no more shoes than feet:

author: William Shakespeare
text: nay, sometime more feet than shoes, or such shoes as my toes look

author: William Shakespeare
text: through the over-leather.

author: William Shakespeare
text: LORD.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Heaven cease this idle humour in your honour!

author: William Shakespeare
text: O, that a mighty man of such descent,

author: William Shakespeare
text: Of such possessions, and so high esteem,

author: William Shakespeare
text: Should be infused with so foul a spirit!

author: William Shakespeare
text: SLY.

author: William Shakespeare
text: What! would you make me mad? Am not I Christopher Sly, old Sly’s son of

author: William Shakespeare
text: Burton-heath; by birth a pedlar, by education a cardmaker, by

author: William Shakespeare
text: transmutation a bear-herd, and now by present profession a tinker? Ask

author: William Shakespeare
text: Marian Hacket, the fat ale-wife of Wincot, if she know me not: if she

author: William Shakespeare
text: say I am not fourteen pence on the score for sheer ale, score me up for

author: William Shakespeare
text: the lyingest knave in Christendom. What! I am not bestraught. Here’s—

author: William Shakespeare
text: THIRD SERVANT.

author: William Shakespeare
text: O! this it is that makes your lady mourn.

author: William Shakespeare
text: SECOND SERVANT.

author: William Shakespeare
text: O! this is it that makes your servants droop.

author: William Shakespeare
text: LORD.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Hence comes it that your kindred shuns your house,

author: William Shakespeare
text: As beaten hence by your strange lunacy.

author: William Shakespeare
text: O noble lord, bethink thee of thy birth,

author: William Shakespeare
text: Call home thy ancient thoughts from banishment,

author: William Shakespeare
text: And banish hence these abject lowly dreams.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Look how thy servants do attend on thee,

author: William Shakespeare
text: Each in his office ready at thy beck:

author: William Shakespeare
text: Wilt thou have music? Hark! Apollo plays,

author: William Shakespeare
text: [Music.]

author: William Shakespeare
text: And twenty caged nightingales do sing:

author: William Shakespeare
text: Or wilt thou sleep? We’ll have thee to a couch

author: William Shakespeare
text: Softer and sweeter than the lustful bed

author: William Shakespeare
text: On purpose trimm’d up for Semiramis.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Say thou wilt walk: we will bestrew the ground:

author: William Shakespeare
text: Or wilt thou ride? Thy horses shall be trapp’d,

author: William Shakespeare
text: Their harness studded all with gold and pearl.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Dost thou love hawking? Thou hast hawks will soar

author: William Shakespeare
text: Above the morning lark: or wilt thou hunt?

author: William Shakespeare
text: Thy hounds shall make the welkin answer them

author: William Shakespeare
text: And fetch shrill echoes from the hollow earth.

author: William Shakespeare
text: FIRST SERVANT.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Say thou wilt course; thy greyhounds are as swift

author: William Shakespeare
text: As breathed stags; ay, fleeter than the roe.

author: William Shakespeare
text: SECOND SERVANT.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Dost thou love pictures? We will fetch thee straight

author: William Shakespeare
text: Adonis painted by a running brook,

author: William Shakespeare
text: And Cytherea all in sedges hid,

author: William Shakespeare
text: Which seem to move and wanton with her breath

author: William Shakespeare
text: Even as the waving sedges play with wind.

author: William Shakespeare
text: LORD.

author: William Shakespeare
text: We’ll show thee Io as she was a maid

author: William Shakespeare
text: And how she was beguiled and surpris’d,

author: William Shakespeare
text: As lively painted as the deed was done.

author: William Shakespeare
text: THIRD SERVANT.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Or Daphne roaming through a thorny wood,

author: William Shakespeare
text: Scratching her legs, that one shall swear she bleeds

author: William Shakespeare
text: And at that sight shall sad Apollo weep,

author: William Shakespeare
text: So workmanly the blood and tears are drawn.

author: William Shakespeare
text: LORD.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Thou art a lord, and nothing but a lord:

author: William Shakespeare
text: Thou hast a lady far more beautiful

author: William Shakespeare
text: Than any woman in this waning age.

author: William Shakespeare
text: FIRST SERVANT.

author: William Shakespeare
text: And, till the tears that she hath shed for thee

author: William Shakespeare
text: Like envious floods o’er-run her lovely face,

author: William Shakespeare
text: She was the fairest creature in the world;

author: William Shakespeare
text: And yet she is inferior to none.

author: William Shakespeare
text: SLY.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Am I a lord? and have I such a lady?

author: William Shakespeare
text: Or do I dream? Or have I dream’d till now?

author: William Shakespeare
text: I do not sleep: I see, I hear, I speak;

author: William Shakespeare
text: I smell sweet savours, and I feel soft things:

author: William Shakespeare
text: Upon my life, I am a lord indeed;

author: William Shakespeare
text: And not a tinker, nor Christophero Sly.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Well, bring our lady hither to our sight;

author: William Shakespeare
text: And once again, a pot o’ the smallest ale.

author: William Shakespeare
text: SECOND SERVANT.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Will’t please your mightiness to wash your hands?

author: William Shakespeare
text: [Servants present a ewer, basin and napkin.]

author: William Shakespeare
text: O, how we joy to see your wit restor’d!

author: William Shakespeare
text: O, that once more you knew but what you are!

author: William Shakespeare
text: These fifteen years you have been in a dream,

author: William Shakespeare
text: Or, when you wak’d, so wak’d as if you slept.

author: William Shakespeare
text: SLY.

author: William Shakespeare
text: These fifteen years! by my fay, a goodly nap.

author: William Shakespeare
text: But did I never speak of all that time?

author: William Shakespeare
text: FIRST SERVANT.

author: William Shakespeare
text: O! yes, my lord, but very idle words;

author: William Shakespeare
text: For though you lay here in this goodly chamber,

author: William Shakespeare
text: Yet would you say ye were beaten out of door,

author: William Shakespeare
text: And rail upon the hostess of the house,

author: William Shakespeare
text: And say you would present her at the leet,

author: William Shakespeare
text: Because she brought stone jugs and no seal’d quarts.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Sometimes you would call out for Cicely Hacket.

author: William Shakespeare
text: SLY.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Ay, the woman’s maid of the house.

author: William Shakespeare
text: THIRD SERVANT.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Why, sir, you know no house nor no such maid,

author: William Shakespeare
text: Nor no such men as you have reckon’d up,

author: William Shakespeare
text: As Stephen Sly, and old John Naps of Greece,

author: William Shakespeare
text: And Peter Turph, and Henry Pimpernell;

author: William Shakespeare
text: And twenty more such names and men as these,

author: William Shakespeare
text: Which never were, nor no man ever saw.

author: William Shakespeare
text: SLY.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Now, Lord be thanked for my good amends!

author: William Shakespeare
text: ALL.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Amen.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Enter the Page, as a lady, with Attendants.

author: William Shakespeare
text: SLY.

author: William Shakespeare
text: I thank thee; thou shalt not lose by it.

author: William Shakespeare
text: PAGE.

author: William Shakespeare
text: How fares my noble lord?

author: William Shakespeare
text: SLY.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Marry, I fare well; for here is cheer enough.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Where is my wife?

author: William Shakespeare
text: PAGE.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Here, noble lord: what is thy will with her?

author: William Shakespeare
text: SLY.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Are you my wife, and will not call me husband?

author: William Shakespeare
text: My men should call me lord: I am your goodman.

author: William Shakespeare
text: PAGE.

author: William Shakespeare
text: My husband and my lord, my lord and husband;

author: William Shakespeare
text: I am your wife in all obedience.

author: William Shakespeare
text: SLY.

author: William Shakespeare
text: I know it well. What must I call her?

author: William Shakespeare
text: LORD.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Madam.

author: William Shakespeare
text: SLY.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Alice madam, or Joan madam?

author: William Shakespeare
text: LORD.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Madam, and nothing else; so lords call ladies.

author: William Shakespeare
text: SLY.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Madam wife, they say that I have dream’d

author: William Shakespeare
text: And slept above some fifteen year or more.

author: William Shakespeare
text: PAGE.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Ay, and the time seems thirty unto me,

author: William Shakespeare
text: Being all this time abandon’d from your bed.

author: William Shakespeare
text: SLY.

author: William Shakespeare
text: ’Tis much. Servants, leave me and her alone.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Madam, undress you, and come now to bed.

author: William Shakespeare
text: PAGE.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Thrice noble lord, let me entreat of you

author: William Shakespeare
text: To pardon me yet for a night or two;

author: William Shakespeare
text: Or, if not so, until the sun be set:

author: William Shakespeare
text: For your physicians have expressly charg’d,

author: William Shakespeare
text: In peril to incur your former malady,

author: William Shakespeare
text: That I should yet absent me from your bed:

author: William Shakespeare
text: I hope this reason stands for my excuse.

author: William Shakespeare
text: SLY.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Ay, it stands so that I may hardly tarry so long; but I would be loath

author: William Shakespeare
text: to fall into my dreams again: I will therefore tarry in despite of the

author: William Shakespeare
text: flesh and the blood.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Enter a Messenger.

author: William Shakespeare
text: MESSENGER.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Your honour’s players, hearing your amendment,

author: William Shakespeare
text: Are come to play a pleasant comedy;

author: William Shakespeare
text: For so your doctors hold it very meet,

author: William Shakespeare
text: Seeing too much sadness hath congeal’d your blood,

author: William Shakespeare
text: And melancholy is the nurse of frenzy:

author: William Shakespeare
text: Therefore they thought it good you hear a play,

author: William Shakespeare
text: And frame your mind to mirth and merriment,

author: William Shakespeare
text: Which bars a thousand harms and lengthens life.

author: William Shakespeare
text: SLY.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Marry, I will; let them play it. Is not a commonty a Christmas gambold

author: William Shakespeare
text: or a tumbling-trick?

author: William Shakespeare
text: PAGE.

author: William Shakespeare
text: No, my good lord; it is more pleasing stuff.

author: William Shakespeare
text: SLY.

author: William Shakespeare
text: What! household stuff?

author: William Shakespeare
text: PAGE.

author: William Shakespeare
text: It is a kind of history.

author: William Shakespeare
text: SLY.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Well, we’ll see’t. Come, madam wife, sit by my side and let the world

author: William Shakespeare
text: slip: we shall ne’er be younger.

author: William Shakespeare

author: William Shakespeare
text: I think thou hast the veriest shrew of all.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Well, I say no; and therefore, for assurance,

author: William Shakespeare
text: Let’s each one send unto his wife,

author: William Shakespeare
text: And he whose wife is most obedient,

author: William Shakespeare
text: To come at first when he doth send for her,

author: William Shakespeare
text: Shall win the wager which we will propose.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Content. What’s the wager?

author: William Shakespeare
text: Twenty crowns.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Twenty crowns!

author: William Shakespeare
text: I’ll venture so much of my hawk or hound,

author: William Shakespeare
text: But twenty times so much upon my wife.

author: William Shakespeare
text: A hundred then.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Content.

author: William Shakespeare
text: A match! ’tis done.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Who shall begin?

author: William Shakespeare
text: That will I.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Go, Biondello, bid your mistress come to me.

author: William Shakespeare
text: I go.

author: William Shakespeare
text: [Exit.]

author: William Shakespeare
text: Son, I’ll be your half, Bianca comes.

author: William Shakespeare
text: I’ll have no halves; I’ll bear it all myself.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Re-enter Biondello.

author: William Shakespeare
text: How now! what news?

author: William Shakespeare
text: Sir, my mistress sends you word

author: William Shakespeare
text: That she is busy and she cannot come.

author: William Shakespeare
text: How! She’s busy, and she cannot come!

author: William Shakespeare
text: Is that an answer?

author: William Shakespeare
text: Ay, and a kind one too:

author: William Shakespeare
text: Pray God, sir, your wife send you not a worse.

author: William Shakespeare
text: I hope better.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Sirrah Biondello, go and entreat my wife

author: William Shakespeare
text: To come to me forthwith.

author: William Shakespeare
text: [Exit Biondello.]

author: William Shakespeare
text: O, ho! entreat her!

author: William Shakespeare
text: Nay, then she must needs come.

author: William Shakespeare
text: I am afraid, sir,

author: William Shakespeare
text: Do what you can, yours will not be entreated.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Re-enter Biondello.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Now, where’s my wife?

author: William Shakespeare
text: She says you have some goodly jest in hand:

author: William Shakespeare
text: She will not come; she bids you come to her.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Worse and worse; she will not come! O vile,

author: William Shakespeare
text: Intolerable, not to be endur’d!

author: William Shakespeare
text: Sirrah Grumio, go to your mistress,

author: William Shakespeare
text: Say I command her come to me.

author: William Shakespeare
text: [Exit Grumio.]

author: William Shakespeare
text: I know her answer.

author: William Shakespeare
text: What?

author: William Shakespeare
text: She will not.

author: William Shakespeare
text: The fouler fortune mine, and there an end.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Re-enter Katherina.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Now, by my holidame, here comes Katherina!

author: William Shakespeare
text: What is your will sir, that you send for me?

author: William Shakespeare
text: Where is your sister, and Hortensio’s wife?

author: William Shakespeare
text: They sit conferring by the parlour fire.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Go fetch them hither; if they deny to come,

author: William Shakespeare
text: Swinge me them soundly forth unto their husbands.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Away, I say, and bring them hither straight.

author: William Shakespeare
text: [Exit Katherina.]

author: William Shakespeare
text: Here is a wonder, if you talk of a wonder.

author: William Shakespeare
text: And so it is. I wonder what it bodes.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Marry, peace it bodes, and love, and quiet life,

author: William Shakespeare
text: An awful rule, and right supremacy;

author: William Shakespeare
text: And, to be short, what not that’s sweet and happy.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Now fair befall thee, good Petruchio!

author: William Shakespeare
text: The wager thou hast won; and I will add

author: William Shakespeare
text: Unto their losses twenty thousand crowns;

author: William Shakespeare
text: Another dowry to another daughter,

author: William Shakespeare
text: For she is chang’d, as she had never been.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Nay, I will win my wager better yet,

author: William Shakespeare
text: And show more sign of her obedience,

author: William Shakespeare
text: Her new-built virtue and obedience.

author: William Shakespeare
text: See where she comes, and brings your froward wives

author: William Shakespeare
text: As prisoners to her womanly persuasion.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Re-enter Katherina with Bianca and Widow.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Katherine, that cap of yours becomes you not:

author: William Shakespeare
text: Off with that bauble, throw it underfoot.

author: William Shakespeare
text: [Katherina pulls off her cap and throws it down.]

author: William Shakespeare
text: Lord, let me never have a cause to sigh

author: William Shakespeare
text: Till I be brought to such a silly pass!

author: William Shakespeare
text: Fie! what a foolish duty call you this?

author: William Shakespeare
text: I would your duty were as foolish too;

author: William Shakespeare
text: The wisdom of your duty, fair Bianca,

author: William Shakespeare
text: Hath cost me a hundred crowns since supper-time!

author: William Shakespeare
text: The more fool you for laying on my duty.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Katherine, I charge thee, tell these headstrong women

author: William Shakespeare
text: What duty they do owe their lords and husbands.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Come, come, you’re mocking; we will have no telling.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Come on, I say; and first begin with her.

author: William Shakespeare
text: She shall not.

author: William Shakespeare
text: I say she shall: and first begin with her.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Fie, fie! unknit that threatening unkind brow,

author: William Shakespeare
text: And dart not scornful glances from those eyes

author: William Shakespeare
text: To wound thy lord, thy king, thy governor:

author: William Shakespeare
text: It blots thy beauty as frosts do bite the meads,

author: William Shakespeare
text: Confounds thy fame as whirlwinds shake fair buds,

author: William Shakespeare
text: And in no sense is meet or amiable.

author: William Shakespeare
text: A woman mov’d is like a fountain troubled,

author: William Shakespeare
text: Muddy, ill-seeming, thick, bereft of beauty;

author: William Shakespeare
text: And while it is so, none so dry or thirsty

author: William Shakespeare
text: Will deign to sip or touch one drop of it.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Thy husband is thy lord, thy life, thy keeper,

author: William Shakespeare
text: Thy head, thy sovereign; one that cares for thee,

author: William Shakespeare
text: And for thy maintenance commits his body

author: William Shakespeare
text: To painful labour both by sea and land,

author: William Shakespeare
text: To watch the night in storms, the day in cold,

author: William Shakespeare
text: Whilst thou liest warm at home, secure and safe;

author: William Shakespeare
text: And craves no other tribute at thy hands

author: William Shakespeare
text: But love, fair looks, and true obedience;

author: William Shakespeare
text: Too little payment for so great a debt.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Such duty as the subject owes the prince,

author: William Shakespeare
text: Even such a woman oweth to her husband;

author: William Shakespeare
text: And when she is froward, peevish, sullen, sour,

author: William Shakespeare
text: And not obedient to his honest will,

author: William Shakespeare
text: What is she but a foul contending rebel

author: William Shakespeare
text: And graceless traitor to her loving lord?—

author: William Shakespeare
text: I am asham’d that women are so simple

author: William Shakespeare
text: To offer war where they should kneel for peace,

author: William Shakespeare
text: Or seek for rule, supremacy, and sway,

author: William Shakespeare
text: When they are bound to serve, love, and obey.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Why are our bodies soft and weak and smooth,

author: William Shakespeare
text: Unapt to toil and trouble in the world,

author: William Shakespeare
text: But that our soft conditions and our hearts

author: William Shakespeare
text: Should well agree with our external parts?

author: William Shakespeare
text: Come, come, you froward and unable worms!

author: William Shakespeare
text: My mind hath been as big as one of yours,

author: William Shakespeare
text: My heart as great, my reason haply more,

author: William Shakespeare
text: To bandy word for word and frown for frown;

author: William Shakespeare
text: But now I see our lances are but straws,

author: William Shakespeare
text: Our strength as weak, our weakness past compare,

author: William Shakespeare
text: That seeming to be most which we indeed least are.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Then vail your stomachs, for it is no boot,

author: William Shakespeare
text: And place your hands below your husband’s foot:

author: William Shakespeare
text: In token of which duty, if he please,

author: William Shakespeare
text: My hand is ready; may it do him ease.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Why, there’s a wench! Come on, and kiss me, Kate.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Well, go thy ways, old lad, for thou shalt ha’t.

author: William Shakespeare
text: ’Tis a good hearing when children are toward.

author: William Shakespeare
text: But a harsh hearing when women are froward.

author: William Shakespeare
text: Come, Kate, we’ll to bed.

author: William Shakespeare
text: We three are married, but you two are sped.

author: William Shakespeare
text: ’Twas I won the wager,

author: William Shakespeare
text: [To Lucentio.] though you hit the white;

author: William Shakespeare
text: And being a winner, God give you good night!

author: William Shakespeare
text: [Exeunt Petruchio and Katherina.]

author: William Shakespeare
text: Now go thy ways; thou hast tam’d a curst shrew.

author: William Shakespeare
text: ’Tis a wonder, by your leave, she will be tam’d so.

author: William Shakespeare
text: [Exeunt.]
